metadata.h1: Using PIL’s Image for image transformation

all_paragraphs: I was recently working on a project that involved manipulating images so we could run an unsupervised machine learning algorithm on it. Being a Python fanboy, rather than going the Photoshop route, I decided to use Python and its libraries to do the manipulation for me.
In this article, I highlight how I used the Image sub module in PIL to create the images I needed for my project.
I took two images for this article, both from Unsplash. I particularly used different sized images so we can access how different sized images might interact with one other.
Note that the first image is wider while the second image is longer in height. We’ll have a lot of fun combining them.
I usually use unsplash.com as it has a humongous variety of high quality images all freely accessible. Obviously, don’t skip on giving proper credit to the artists. It’s good ethics!!
I am using Python 3.6 here but all versions of Python 3.5 and above should ideally work.

The Pillow is the PIL package containing our sub module Image. I’ve also decided to install matplotlib because it just makes it easier to display images within a Jupyter notebook irrespective of the size of the image. For example, when I tried to directly display the image using Image, it opened a new window with the image all full blown up.
If you want to do this in Jupyter notebooks, install it using pip install jupyter, start the Jupyter server and create a new notebook.

We’ll now load in the installed libraries. We need the Image sub module from PIL and the pyplot sub module from matplotlib which we will load in by the name plt. You can really name it anything or nothing at all, it’s just common practice to use plt.

It's very very easy to resize an image using Image. We just use the resize() method and define a tuple for the (width, height) of the final resized image. In the code below, I resize the image 1 to 1200x800, then print the size of the old and the new image, and finally display the resultant image.
Look at the horizontal and vertical axis and you’ll see that the new image is now resized to the size 1200x800.

In my project, I had to combine several images one after the other horizontally. The idea was to have images with the same height but with increasing width. Once I started looking for possible solutions, I was able to write a code that worked. However, unlike square images in my project, I was curious if I could combine different sized images and generate usable images. After careful experimentation, I found a solution that would work for images with varying sizes.

I start by creating a new image using Image.new(). The first argument states that I’m creating an RGB image and the second argument is the width and height of the final image. It’s quite obvious to see that when two images will be placed side by side, their width would simply add up. However, as the heights of the two would be different, using a min() method would shrink the combined image to the appropriate height so there is no blank space.
I then paste the first image starting at (0,0) and the second image where the first image ends by (img1.width, 0). The resultant image is below:

Just like horizontal concatenation, we can also combine images vertically. For that the total height would be the sum of the heights of the two images and the width would be the minimum of the two.
Here, we’ll paste image 1 again at (0,0) but the second image will be placed at (0, img1.height). Again, we used the min() method here in place of the max() method.
